intro: Allium fistulosum var. viviparum, commonly known as the garlic chive or Chinese chive, is a variant of the common garlic chive, characterized by its ability to produce bulbils along its flower stalks. This plant is a perennial herb native to Asia and is widely cultivated for its edible leaves and bulbils. It belongs to the Amaryllidaceae family and is closely related to other Allium species such as garlic and leeks. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with slender, hollow stems and narrow, grass-like leaves. Its flowers are small and clustered in umbels, and it thrives in temperate climates with well-drained soil.
